Army of the Dead has a solid premise - a zombie heist set in a quarantined Las Vegas is undeniably exciting. But somewhere between concept and execution, the story loses its footing and never quite recovers.

The characters are so fundamentally underwritten that the few who actually deserve attention are pushed to the sidelines like Coyote and Dieter, and I would have liked to see more from Peters, yet we barely see enough of them to care. 
Instead, we’re force-fed a focus on Scott and Kate, which is genuinely baffling. Scott, okay fine he’s the designated lead. But Kate? What cosmic purpose does she serve? She is just simply… there.

The entire subplot where Kate wanders off to rescue Geeta feels like it was stapled onto the script during a coffee break. Are we meant to believe she’s suddenly a savior of the oppressed? Nothing in the film builds that foundation. One sad glance at a group of kids does not create a character arc. And as for some of the other characters, I won’t waste oxygen discussing motivations that barely exist.

To the film’s credit, the idea of zombies evolving into a structured society with hierarchy and leadership is genuinely fascinating. Had it been introduced with care or explored with depth, it could have set this movie apart. Instead, it’s rushed, overshadowed, and ultimately feels like an afterthought buried beneath chaos and noise.

A bold concept, strong visuals, and a premise brimming with potential and yet Army of the Dead ends up a massively missed opportunity to deliver something great. Still, with lowered expectations, I would say it's a solid one time watch.

Army of the Dead was a Netflix movie about zombies in Las Vegas. Naturally a casino heist is involved so cue "putting the team together" montage and then add in zombie tigers, zombie horses, robot zombies, martial arts zombies, even pregnant zombies. The action is fine, CGI is marginal at best, Dave Bautista is good, but the way the movie is shot with the blurred background gets annoying fast. Overall, the run time is too long, the plot is silly, but if you like zombie movies then you might like this.

“Army of the Dead” is a thrilling cinematic experience that brilliantly blends action, horror, and a touch of dark humor. The movie’s intense pace keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish, with each scene carefully crafted to deliver maximum impact. David Bautista’s performance is nothing short of extraordinary; he brings a deep, emotional complexity to his character that adds a surprising layer of depth to the film. His portrayal of a conflicted hero navigating the chaos of a zombie-infested Las Vegas is both compelling and memorable. The ensemble cast, stunning visuals, and innovative take on the zombie genre make “Army of the Dead” a must-watch for fans of action-packed thrillers. It’s a masterful blend of storytelling and spectacle, and it’s easily one of the best movies of its kind.
